messageBody:
On 8/8/05, Jeff Grigg <jeffgrigg@...> wrote:
> > --- Jeff Grigg wrote:
> >> [...] Testing get and set methods is typically a waste
> >> of time. [...]
>
> --- Elliotte Harold <elharo@m...> wrote:
> > A popular myth. I've lost count of how many bugs I've found
> > in set and get methods, as well as other methods that were
> > "too simple to fail."
>
> True; very true.

Amen!

> But, I've also seen teams fail by putting nearly all of their
> testing effort into testing each and every get and set method -- >>>
> and almost nothing else! <<< So they have lots of tests -- but poor
> coverage, and just about no coverage of any business logic that
> matters. "But we wrote lots of tests!" they say.

So? There will always be foolish people. I've clocked up my fair share
of years in this industry and I tell you that I have seen both good
and bad since I started. However, their foolishness does not mean that
I am going to throw aside testing.

> Rarely have I seen simple get or set methods fail. And recently,
> when it happened, I wrote *one* test, using reflection, to test
> *all* the get and set methods in the whole system.

I'm still keen on testing accessors, because they can and do break.
I've seen the error messages with my own eyes! If you want to test
them using reflection, that's fine. In fact, that may make the most
sense. But you did test them, because you found they could break. :-)

> (Rational Rose has a bad habit of deleting method bodies when doing
> round-trip engineering. You gotta watch for that.)

Rational Rose is over-hyped, over-priced and over here (to borrow a phrase).

Simon
